Content Description
The Alan Snitow and Deborah Kaufman Research Files on the American Jewish Congress contain a collection of Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) files related to the American Jewish Congress (AJC). Snitow and Kaufman used these files for research on the documentary “Between Two Worlds” produced by their company, Snitow-Kaufman Productions in 2011. The documentary focused on communist purges within the American Jewish Congress. The collection contains correspondence related to Alan Snitow’s Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) requests to the FBI on the American Jewish Congress as well as several other individuals and organizations. The collection also contains FBI files on the Anti-Fascist Refugee Committee, Billie Portnow, Judith Pollack, Stanley Levison, Shad and Justine Polier, and the American Jewish Committee. Alan Snitow also submitted FOIA requests for files on his parents Virginia Levitt Snitow and Charles Snitow, but those files are not included in the collection.

Historical Note
Alan Snitow and Deborah Kaufman collected Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) files in this collection for a documentary on communist purges in the American Jewish Congress (AJC). Snitow and Kaufman’s company Snitow-Kaufman Productions began working on the project in 2009 for the Public Broadcasting Service (PBS) series “POV” under the title “Discontinuity,” but eventually released the documentary under the title, “Between Two Worlds” in 2011. Snitow and Kaufman submitted several Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) requests to gain access to files on the American Jewish Congress, as well as individuals related to the communist purges for research on the documentary. Requests for files on individuals included those of Alan Snitow’s parents Virginia Levitt Snitow and Charles Snitow who were members of the Communist Party and the American Jewish Congress. Responding to multiple requests, the FBI also released files on the American Jewish Committee, which they may have confused with the American Jewish Congress.
